title: 114_s595
content: The "Hunter and Farmer Protection Act of 2015" allows for the baiting of migratory game birds. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act is amended to prohibit baiting of migratory game birds by defining a baited area as any place where salt, grain, or feed is used to attract these birds. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act prohibits baiting of migratory game birds by defining a baited area as any place where salt, grain, or feed is used to attract these birds. Baiting means the direct manipulation of a standing, unharvested crop through activities like mowing, discing, or rolling, unless it is a normal agricultural practice. An area is not considered baited if it has been treated with a normal agricultural practice, has standing crops that have not been manipulated, or has standing crops that have been flooded. The Migratory Bird Treaty Act defines baiting as the placement of salt, grain, or feed to attract migratory game birds. Migratory game birds include species within specific taxonomic families with open hunting seasons designated by the Secretary of the Interior. The term 'normal agricultural practice' refers to any practice in one growing season aimed at producing a marketable crop, as recommended by the State office of the Cooperative Extension System of the Department of Agriculture. The term 'normal agricultural practice' includes the destruction of a crop in accordance with practices required by the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation for agricultural producers to obtain crop insurance under the Federal Crop Insurance Act. The term 'normal agricultural practice' includes the destruction of a crop in the current or immediately preceding crop year due to a natural disaster declared a major disaster by the President. The term 'normal agricultural practice' includes crop destruction through activities like mowing, discing, or rolling, certified by the Federal Crop Insurance Corporation. 'Waterfowl' refers to native species of the Anatidae family. The prohibition of taking migratory game birds by baiting or placing bait to induce hunting is regulated by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit an annual report on this matter. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report to the Secretary of the Interior describing changes in agricultural practices across different regions of the United States where recommendations are provided to agricultural producers.
